definition:
The aminopenicillins
are a group of &%Antibiotics in the &%Penicillin family that are
structural analogs of ampicillin (which is the 2-amino derivative of
benzylpenicillin, hence the name). Like other penicillins and
beta-lactam antibiotics, they contain a beta-lactam ring that is
crucial to its antibacterial activity. Aminopenicillins feature a
positively charged amino group that enhances their uptake through
bacterial porin channels. This does not, however, prevent resistance
conferred by bacterial beta-lactamases. Members of this family
include ampicillin, amoxicillin and bacampicillin.[from Wikipedia]
